Posts.Content: Aug 18, 2011 08:54PM ScaredInSnoqualmie wrote: I just had my MRI done today.  I am not claustrophobic, so I wouldn't begin to understand how people with the phobia would feel, but for me, it was almost a humorous experience:  I had my headphones with Vivaldi playing (note for the future: do NOT choose Vivaldi:)), and when the "noises" started, and I couldn't hear any music, I started playing mental game with myself, trying to pretend the noises were actually the same word, repeated over and over; I picked  different words, depending on the type of noise, and oddly, this greatly distracted me and calmed me - the whole 20 minute procedure went by pretty quickly:)  I wish you the best of luck with this and other steps towards your recovery... Tatiana
Posts.Title: Scanxiety carcharm Kate33

Posts.Content: Aug 22, 2011 06:27AM - edited Aug 22, 2011 06:28AM by ScaredInSnoqualmie Wow... I just realized something... Looked at your profile and noticed you had 40% risk of cancer and you went through the mastectomy... I guess I am not overreacting at all, and even if I am not BRACA positive, and my biopsy comes negative, I still have LCIS and my Mom had cancer twice, and I have an autoimmune desease and according to my surgeon my risk is over 50%,  so... I think I should just go for it, right?

Posts.Content: Aug 25, 2011 05:32AM - edited Aug 25, 2011 05:36AM by ScaredInSnoqualmie Lisamg:  duh... figured out HOW to use this message board... must be the aenestesia:)  Anyway, I did sent you a private message, once again, thanks for your input, this was the same surgeon who, when asked about Tamoxifen and Hashimoto patients, shrugged it off by saying" I have plenty of thyroid patients on Tamoxifen and they are fine, so you will be fine"  Something tells me it is time to at least a second (third, fourth?) opinion.  Will keep you updated... SpecialK: I am SO SORRY to hear you had to endure 6 surgeries!  You must be a very tough cookie...  Thanks for your input as well, I am definitely going to look around and see what other specialists I could go consult with... I am not completely sure yet that I will be taking the prophilactic bilateral mastectomy route yet, but leaning towards it, if my biopsy comes back with a cancer result

Posts.Content: Sep 1, 2011 05:21AM - edited Sep 1, 2011 05:22AM by ScaredInSnoqualmie Momoschki:sorry, somehow I missed responding to this one:  I am very interested in this research re breast reduction as a form of prevention.  I have a breast reduction scheduled for October 7th by my plastic surgeon.  My logic behind proceeding with it is that I have planned it before the diagnosis anyway, I am not quite ready for a mastectomy yet, and so, why not get the right size breasts now and maybe have an option of keeping my nipples later with a sparing mastectomy?  So... is there a particular way your surgeons approached your reduction from what the usual protocol is and if so, where can I learn about it and educate my surgeon before he cuts? Tatiana

Posts.Content: Aug 25, 2011 03:30AM - edited Aug 25, 2011 03:31AM by ScaredInSnoqualmie Sorry I didn't write for a couple of days... It got too overwhelming and I needed a mental break from information:)  Here is my update:  MRI came back totally clear.  Had my surgical biopsy done today, still groggy from sedative (insisted on twilight sedation instead of full aenestesia - so glad I did, as I always throw up afterwards, no matter how many heroic efforts they undertake to prevent it, haha).  Also groggy from the antibiotic, because, naturally, I had an allergic reaction, no surprises here.  So... benandril is my friend:)  For now, I just have to wait on the biopsy results.  My surgeon told me I am not even in a risk factor group for genetic testing, because my Mom had BC after her menapause, and although I do have  Eastern European Ashkenazi background, it is on my father's, not my mother's side?  Thought that was interesting... BS also added that, if I DO have cancer at the moment, then I AM in the risk group for BRCA mutation and then she would recommend I test.  I am thinking, in this scenario, if there IS a cancer diagnosis, even if I am NOT positive, I should still have my prophilactic mastectomy, what do you ladies think?  And, of course, IF it is cancer and if I am positive, then it is a no-brainer... But....what if there is no cancer?  Do I still insist on the testing?  And, if the testing is negative, then what?  Any input, pro and con would be highly appreciated:) Tatiana
Posts.Title: Has anyone had a nipple-sparing skin sparing mastectomy? ScaredInSnoqualmie momoschki

Posts.Content: Aug 26, 2011 08:31PM ScaredInSnoqualmie wrote: So... my biopsy results are in :  according to the surgeon on duty today, they found "nothing".  I was so happy I didn't question his statement that there is no additional LCIS?  But now I am thinking, how can it be that the needle biopsy shows LCIS and the surgical one shows NOTHING?  Could it be that they didn't reach the right area?  Anyway, when I asked him what my next step should be, he said that I could take Tamoxifen.  When I asked him if I needed a 6moth follow-up mammo, he said "No"...  Seems really strange... Oh, well... Will go for my breast reduction, and who knows, maybe pathology will show something else...  It is just strange to stay so anxious for the whole week, considering prophilactic mastectomy and now... nothing needs to be done?  I am definitely going for a second opinion, but would appreciate any input here as well.  Thanks:) Tatiana

In your picture you look gorgeous and young... Posts.Content: Aug 19, 2011 05:24PM ScaredInSnoqualmie wrote: I am considering a prophilactic bilateral mastectomy right now.  August 17th was supposed to be my breast-reduction surgery day.  On August 8th, a repeat 6-month mammo showed "suspicious" cells and the biospy showed pre-cancerous cells.  I am waiting the results of the MRI right now. After crying and raging for 2 days straight, here is where I am a  the moment:  if the result comes back as cancer, I am having a bilateral mastectomy.  If it comes back as NOT cancer, but my genetic test comes back positive, I am having a bilateral mastectomy.  My mother had BC twice and the second time it almost killed her.  I don't want to freak out every 6 months for the rest of my life.  As far a tamoxifen goes, from what I have read so far, I will not take it - here is a link to an article you might find helpful:  http://www.all-natural.com/tamox.html So... My heart goes out to you, I know exactly what you are going through (well, not the physical part, haven't done it yet, but the emotions... Sucks big time).  You did a brave and a rational thing. Tatiana
